unnormalised: Gastroenterology, a field of medicine that’s becoming increasingly important here in India, especially with our changing lifestyles. I remember my own grandfather, Dada-ji, suffering from acidity almost every day. He'd always say, "Beta, yeh bhaga-daudh wali life mein kuch toh hoga hi pet ko." Turns out, he was right, gastro problems are super common now.

unnormalised: One of the big issues is GERD, or Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease. You know, that burning sensation in your chest after eating spicy samosas? Yeah, that's probably it. A lot of doctors, like Dr. Sharma at AIIMS, are seeing more and more patients with GERD these days. Then there's IBS, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, which can be a real pain – bloating, constipation, sometimes even needing to rush to the loo after just 1 bite of chilli chicken. There are medications available, like Spasmindon forte. The tricky thing is, it's different for everyone, so finding the right treatment sometimes feels like trial and error.

unnormalised: Talking about treatments, apart from popping pills, lifestyle changes are huge. Less oily food, regular exercise (yoga helps!), and managing stress – easier said than done, I know! But seriously, avoiding late-night parathas and trying to sleep by 11:00 PM can make a world of difference. There are also some "desi" remedies that people swear by, like ajwain water for indigestion, but always check with your doctor first.

unnormalised: Colonoscopies are also increasingly common. My uncle had one done at Apollo Hospitals last year and he was dreading it but said it was surprisingly easy (after the prep, that is!). Docs recommend you get one after 50 yrs of age generally. It's basically a way to screen for anything nasty, like colon cancer, early on. It's a little expensive, costing upwards of Rs. 10,000 in some places, but definitely worth considering, especially if you have a family history.

unnormalised: So, take care of your gut, folks! It’s more important than you think. Listen to your body, eat healthy, and don't ignore those tummy rumbles. A happy tummy means a happy you, as they say! And if things get really bad, don't hesitate to see a gastroenterologist. It’s better to be safe than sorry, bhai!
